fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
A (set-)function consists of two sets, the domain and the codomain, and a rule (say, a derivation) that assigns to each element of the domain a unique element of the codomain.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.

fr:title.text: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Lawvere's elementary theory of the category of sets asserts that the category of sets is the well-pointed topos with choice and a natural numbers object.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
An surjection is an epimorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is surjective if, for every y\in B, there exists an x\in A such that f(x)=y.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.
The empty set \varnothing is the initial object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with no elements.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
The cartesian product is the product in Set. Explicitly, the product of sets A and B is A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a\in A, b\in B\}.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
The function set is the exponential in Set. Explicitly, the function set of sets A and B is the set of functions B^A := \{f: A\to B\}.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
The union A \cup B of two subsets A,B\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\in A\text { or }x\in B\}.
The intersection A \cup B of two subsets A,B\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\in A\text { and }x\in B\}.
The complement A^c of a subset A\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\notin A\}.

fr:title.text: Complete Boolean algebra structure on power sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complete Boolean algebra structure on power sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The power set 2^X of a set X forms a complete Boolean algebra under union, intersection, and complement.
The natural numbers \mathbb {N} = \{0, 1, \dots \} are the natural numbers object in Set.

The integers \mathbb {Z} = \{\dots , -1, 0, 1, \dots \} are the quotient of the square \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N} of the natural numbers by the relation (n, m)\sim (n', m') \text { iff } n + m' = n' + m.

The rational numbers \mathbb {Q} are the quotient of the product \mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z}\setminus 0 of the integers with the integers without zero by the relation (p, q)\sim (p', q')\text { iff } pq' = qp'.
The real numbers \mathbb {R} are TODO.

Let X/\sim be a quotient of a space X. Then the quotient topology on X/\sim is the final topology with respect to the projection X\xtwoheadrightarrow {\pi } X/\sim . It thus has the following universal property: a set-function X/\sim \,\xrightarrow {f} Z is continuous if and only if the composite X\xrightarrow {\pi }X/\sim \,\xrightarrow {f}Z is.
Explicitly, the open subsets of X/\sim are exactly the subsets U\subseteq X/\sim so that \pi ^{-1}(U) is open in X.

fr:title.text: Construction of the tensor product of modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of the tensor product of modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We give an explicit construction of the tensor product of modules M and N, in two stages. First, when R = \mathbb {Z}, so M and N are just abelian groups, the tensor product is the free abelian group on M\times N, whose elements are written m\otimes n, modulo the relations generated by addition in M and N: m_1\otimes n + m_2 \otimes n = (m_1 + m_2)\otimes n\quad \text {and}\quad m \otimes n_1 + m \otimes n_2 = m \otimes (n_1 + n_2). Next, for arbitrary R, the tensor product is the tensor product of the underlying abelian groups modulo the action of R: (rm)\otimes n = r(m\otimes n) = m\otimes (rn). Alternatively, it is the coequalizer of the two maps M\otimes R\otimes N\rightrightarrows M\otimes N given by acting on M and on N.

The integers \mathbb {Z} = \{\dots , -1, 0, 1, \dots \} are the quotient of the square \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N} of the natural numbers by the relation (n, m)\sim (n', m') \text { iff } n + m' = n' + m.

fr:title.text: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The localization C_S of a category C at S is exhibited by the following (not necessarily small) construction:

fr:ul.fr:li: the objects of C_S are those of C;

a morphism in C_S is a zig-zag of morphisms in C, where the "rightward" maps consist only of those in S, modulo the relations generated by composition, the identities, and the equations x\xrightarrow {s}y\xleftarrow {s}x \sim 1_x and y\xleftarrow {s}x\xrightarrow {s} y \sim 1_y whenever s\in S.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The embedding Q sends x\xrightarrow {f} y to the "singleton" zig-zag x\xrightarrow {f} y, and inverts S by construction. To exhibit the universal property, suppose C\xrightarrow {F} D is given and inverts S. Then define F_S on a zig-zag by mapping it over the zig-zag and composing in D. The diagram commutes on the nose (note in particular that the relations on C_S don't break this, because they hold in D as well; this is essentially the universal property of the quotient), so it remains to show the uniqueness property. But the functor must act appropriately on the inclusion and preserve composites, so this is immediate.
Let N\unlhd G. Then the quotient group G/N is the quotient object of the induced congruence; explicitly, it is the set of cosets of N in G with the operation (gN)(hN) = (gh)N.

To show that this defines a group, note that the induced equivalence relation is a congruence, hence compatible with the group multiplication, so that the multiplication is well-defined. The group axioms are direct from those of G.

To exhibit the universal property, let G\xrightarrow {f} H be any homomorphism which is constant on equivalence classes. Since G/N is also the quotient set, It suffices to show that the induced set-function \tilde {f} is a homomorphism: \tilde {f}(ghN) = f(gh) = f(g)f(h) = \tilde {f}(g)\tilde {f}(h).

The free group on a set X is the group whose elements are group words in X, i.e. finite strings x_1^{\epsilon _1}\dots x_r^{\epsilon _r}, where x_i\in i and \epsilon _i\in \{-1, 1\}, modulo the relation generated by reducing adjacent pairs x^{\pm 1}x^{\mp 1}, with multiplication by concatenation.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
A quotient object x/r is the coequalizer of a congruence r\xrightarrow {r_1,r_2} x.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
